questions.question_text:
A security administrator needs to configure a firewall rule based on the domain name of a specific application.

Which field in a distributed firewall rule does the administrator configure?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Based on 2v0-41.20 questions, seems to be Profile.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T-Data-Center/3.1/administration/GUID-63262728-CA72-47D2-8E4F-16617B63A9A4.html

Selected Answer: A
For a distributed firewall rule to match traffic based on the domain name of a specific application, the administrator would configure the "profile" field of the rule.

Profile - Additional criteria like user, URL category, domain etc

The "policy" field in NSX is for assigning security policies to objects, rather than directly defining rule matching logic. So the "profile" field is used to inject domain/URL inspection into the rule match.

Selected Answer: A
I suppose you can properly use FQDN only in the Context Profile field.

Selected Answer: D
In a distributed firewall rule, the policy field is used to define the criteria that must be met for the rule to be applied. This criteria can include the source and destination IP addresses, the port numbers, and the domain name of the application.

The other answer choices are incorrect:

Profile: The profile field is used to specify the security context profile that should be applied to the rule.
Service: The service field is used to specify the port number or protocol that the rule should apply to.
Source: The source field is used to specify the source IP address or range of IP addresses that the rule should apply to.
Here is an example of a distributed firewall rule that is configured to allow traffic to a specific application based on the domain name

Selected Answer: B
Service is correctly...

questions.question_text: Which two statements are correct about East-West Malware Prevention? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Answer: AC
ICM 4.0 course:
East-west malware prevention has the following requirements:
The NSX environment must be configured with a valid license for malware prevention.
At a minimum, NSX Application Platform must be deployed with the Standard form factor in the environment.
The thin agent must be installed on every guest VM.
NSX Application Platform must have Internet access
And:
Each ESXi host includes a service virtual machine (SVM), which inspects all files that are downloaded at the guest level.

Selected Answer: AC
Saw in the ICM 4.0

Selected Answer: BC
Edge nodes need inet access and a svm needs to be deployed on every esxi host

choices.A: NSX Application Platform must have Internet access.
choices.D: An agent must be installed on every NSX Edge node.
choices.B: NSX Edge nodes must have Internet access.
choices.C: A SVM is deployed on every ESXi host.
choices.E: An agent must be installed on every ESXi host.

questions.question_text: Which table on an ESXi host is used to determine the location of a particular workload for a frame-forwarding decision?

choices.A: Create a SAML authentication in VMware Identity Manager using the NSX Manager FQDN.
choices.D: Add NSX Manager as a Service Provider (SP) in VMware Identity Manager.
choices.B: Enter the Identity Provider (IdP) metadata URL in NSX Manager.
choices.C: Create an OAuth 2.0 client in VMware Identity Manager.
choices.E: Enter the service URL, Client Secret, and SSL thumbprint in NSX Manager.

questions.question_text: Which two steps must an NSX administrator take to integrate VMware Identity Manager in NSX to support role-based access control? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Answer: CE
ICM 4.0:
After both NSX and VMware Identity Manager appliances are deployed and configured, you can integrate these components:
Create an OAuth client for NSX in VMware Identity Manager.
Obtain the SHA-256 certificate thumbprint for the VMware Identity Manager appliance.
Configure the VMware Identity Manager details in NSX.

Selected Answer: BC
No reason to choose anything besides BC, really. Aria is about monitoring and Tanzu is conteinerisation solution.
